storyInfo: Learning the news of Golding's death, in discouragement and bewilderment amidst the Self-Salvation Corps' heavy losses, Heidi heads for the school in the city center.

attributes.text: \n\nSince the news, it's grown hard to put pen to paper.
\n\nI want to convey my grief, pain, anger, confusion, and I want to offer you consolation, all too late.
But the things you've said, and left unsaid, I understand equally. The despair that's driven you to sever all, to choose to give up on this life, that too I understand.
\n\nWhat else can I possibly write? All I could say, you surely already know.

attributes.content: *sigh*...
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Be strong, sir... this is all the first-aid I can give right now.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: It'll be a little unbearable at first, but you'll be able to walk with enough effort. And if any Sarkaz come after you again, you'll be able to flee too.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Hahah. Thank you, madam...
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: I don't know who you are exactly, but I swear I've spotted you around before. You must be one of Lady Golding's like-minded friends.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: ...Yes.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Were you going to find her at the school? She's not with us anymore, exactly.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: I know. Mm—I learned as much a while ago.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Please, save your strength. We need to leave this place as soon as we can. I fear that Sarkaz detachment will be back soon to sweep this area.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: So we've escaped. Now what?
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Do you remember delivering a letter for Golding? Do you remember the distillery worker you contacted?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: If you're lost for any place to go, then seek him, and follow the trail from his place to flee the city.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I can't guarantee your safety; the line that intel came from is out of service by now. But if you do opt for it as a last resort, then you may ultimately find your way to some of the Self-Salvation Corps.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: No, or perhaps you'll find some... doctors. People similar enough to them, that is.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I'd wanted to seize on her letter as an opportunity, introduce her to the Doctor, to Kal'tsit...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: ...In any case, go quickly. Each passing moment here is a moment in danger.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: And what about you?
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: You needn't worry about that. I have ways to hide myself.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: After all, there's plenty of ruins and rubble the Sarkaz have no interest in sweeping now, here in our grand old Londinium.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: The Self-Salvation Corps will return, you know. Someone has to stay here to keep things prepared for them.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: That's wonderful, then. You know which way you should be going—so don't go sticking your neck out for me, now.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: You mean—oh, don't say that, sir.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I know, you know. Strange armies beyond the walls, and plenty chance of Sarkaz in any of the countless underground ways out.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: And where you plucked me free, that pile of rubble? That was my home... Hahah, I'm the same really. Yearning to see what isn't even there anymore.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Now's no time to lose heart. I've heard word of others, too, Self-Salvation Corps aside.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Sarkaz forces may be outside the city, but the dukes are about to formally enter their own troops into the fray. The blockades will soon be dusted aside, the Sarkaz will no longer seal the city entrance, and it'll be wide open again...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Thank you. But, well...
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: I can only imagine how well you knew Lady Golding.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: I only met her a scant few times, but I remember every time I took a letter from her hands, how gently she'd encourage me, just as you did now.
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: And so, from time to time these days, I wonder...
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Why would someone like her choose to give up on her own life?
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Why, madam?
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Just walking takes some wind out of me, dragging my heavy leg. Could you go to the school for me and find an answer there?
attributes.name: Londinium Citizen

attributes.content: Settle down, Leo!
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: The Colonel may turn a blind eye for us, but the school is not safe anymore!
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: —Urgh!
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Did you hear that outside?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Even a single falling rock could spell our little classroom caving in...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: But I'm not scared! Bwooom, bwoooom... I'm not scared of them!
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Shut it, not a word! Lady Golding would—
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Ah, excuse me, er...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Hello, Molly. I'm a friend of Golding.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I remember now, Lady Heidi... but I'm sorry, I'll have to ask you to leave.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Wait. Why?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: If you wanted Lady Golding, she's been out of the school lately. I'm not sure where it is she's fled to, actually.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: I don't mean this against you, but... as you see, everyone's in crisis now. I don't want anyone inviting more danger upon the schoolchildren.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Did I frighten you, perhaps? You seem very out of sorts.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Ah, do I...? No, it wasn't you.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: It's just, so much has happened lately. How could one not be on edge?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: I really don't know how I'm even meant to protect these children, coping by myself...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: ...I'm sorry, Molly.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: If the Sarkaz do come knocking, then be forthcoming. Tell them I'm here.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: You ARE in their sights, then?!
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Please, let me shelter inside for a spell. If that's okay?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I don't know... What happened to you?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: I am a friend of Golding's... if that explains anything.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: To my mind, there's one place to hide within the school. Lady Golding didn't want me letting any old passerby know, but, well, you're no passerby.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Leo, take Lady Heidi to the underground 'storehouse', would you?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: I'll stay here and wait. If Sarkaz soldiers do barge in, I'll... I'll find some way or other.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Leo, may I ask you a few questions?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Go on, ask.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: What kind of place is this underground 'storehouse'?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: You'll know it when you see it.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Is it a refuge connecting to the sewers?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: ...Who even are you?
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: A friend of Miss Golding's from the literary circles, that's all.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: No need to be so astonished. After all, I've heard more than plenty about this school, and the children she taught.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Still... did Molly never actually tell you all that it's... not safe down there anymore?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Haven't heard anything like that. My family and a bunch of others too, they're all hiding in there.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: (Does Molly really have no clue about the Self-Salvation Corps' retreat? Or could it be...)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Well, then, has Miss Molly seemed strange in any way, as of recent?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Strange? Nah, no way. You don't get to say mean things about her.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: But... there's some things about her that we can't really figure out.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: She's there every day, always fussing over us, and going on and on at us all the time, but then one day she suddenly ran to us and said she'd been cooped up by the Sarkaz for days on end, and thank god we're okay, and stuff.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: And ever since then she's always been all nervy, like she had a nightmare, and it's scared her stiff.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: (The Damazti.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (I was only speculating at first. This place was one of the leaks in the Corps' intelligence network, so I suspected Molly had turned traitor, but now...)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (If the Damazti's found its way in, then... could even the boy before me be one of its transformations?)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (No, even if there was no sign of that shapeshifter, I'd... suspect them all anyway.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Hey! Where are you going?
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Didn't you hear what Miss Molly said? You've got to go into the basement, down the stairs. That's the wrong way.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Listen to me, Leo.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Could you do me a favor, and let me take a walk around school on my own? You can go back and tell Miss Molly that I'm sheltered well now.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Saying so, Heidi carefully observes how he reacts.
No, you're fibbing.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Unless you help me with a thing, too.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: What might that be?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I want to do this ruddy Sarkaz in, but everyone says I can't go.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Humph! How come he gets to be so mean!
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Uncle Jack lives in the alley over there, he's really nice, but then that Sarkaz gave him a beating, and locked him up, and it's been days now.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: I saw through a crack in the window, his arms and legs all bent into this shape. It must be horrible being twisted like that. I wanna get him free.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: The child's expression remains clear, unadulterated. Heidi knows; if he was the Damazti, he'd have no need to make up this lie for himself.
But she does wish to herself, for an instant, that this was not the true student of Golding, the eleven-year-old boy.
No. Assaulting a Sarkaz would only be asking for further trouble, you understand.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: And, well... I presume this Uncle Jack you mention was left there with his limbs broken; he must have... long breathed his last.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I could explain to you the kind of brute violence the Sarkaz dole out to civilians, and why we have to endure, to protect ourselves, but...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Doesn't matter.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: If you're not going, forget it.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: You're right... Explaining it doesn't matter.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I'm not stupid. I figured that much.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: I just hate it, it feels horrible. Uncle Jack like that, I keep seeing it.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: (If Golding were here, I'm sure she would pained so to see the children in this state.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (But... she at least taught them, for when tragedy visits them, to hold onto their sense of pain.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Leo.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: To tell the truth, I'm... here to check on where Golding used to live.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: There's no need to hide it. I've heard the news of her death.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: When she wasn't holding your lessons, where would she usually be?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Um, the bookshop, and the corridors if they were sunny... and, right, she had an office.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: But she didn't stay inside there much. And it was always locked, too, when she was in and when she was out.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Hm... Is it the room over that way?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Did she tell you about it?
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: She's described to me, many a time, the scene one can peek through the cracks in the closed shutters. She said a broken lamppost stood outside the window. Damaged by a Sarkaz at some point, and nobody dared to go touch it.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Oh, okay. Well, anyway, it's locked—
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: —That's smoke, isn't it?!
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: Where would the fire be?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: No, wait, it's a signal. There's Sarkaz coming close to the 'storehouse'.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: That's...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Yes, this happens with the school's basement. Lt. Colonel Lettou realized as much long ago.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Is someone down there? No, they can't be. Who would come out to a place like this?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Even back when the school still had plenty of students, a long while ago, you see, we'd throw any odds and ends we had no place to keep down there. Scrap catching itself on fire has, well, happened more than once in the school's history.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: That's why you smelled smoke. I thought something wasn't right about the air either, so I came down to check.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: (She's... trembling. But she's still keeping the students away, all by herself.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (Maybe I was just apprehensive, and she's innocent after all.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (Lettou's Sarkaz aren't too obedient to him, and wouldn't trust her either.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: (She just glanced that way. That's where the others should be concealed.)
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Leo, can you trust me now? Would you like to try taking down that Sarkaz a different way?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Go on.
attributes.name: Naughty Child

attributes.content: We'll try and lure them all off.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Phew...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Thank you for saving us all!
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Oh, you're hurt...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: That's fine, just a little trickle—anything to get out of that rubble and scrap metal faster. We're lucky Leo isn't hurt.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: ...Lady Heidi?! Why are you pointing your cane at me?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Don't be too nervous; I just want to ask you one simple question. If you answer correctly, I'll be convinced of your trustworthiness.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: What was the first thing Clovisia ever said to you?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: What...? I don't recall this name, I'm not sure who you're telling me about, I'm sorry...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: That's alright, Molly, thank you.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I apologize—when I told you I was being tailed before, that was just a lie meant to feel you out...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Now I trust that you still love every child of this school, as you always earnestly have.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Also, you are completely unaware of the changes that transpired in this time.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: In this time... You're right, yes. I've missed a great deal.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Listen to me. The Victorians that used to be active in Londinium's underground have suffered heavy losses. The Citizens' Self-Salvation Corps' network is unable to reach anybody.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Moreover, I didn't note being shadowed when I came, but the Sarkaz have appeared here.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I fear they've suspected this place for a while now, and Lt. Colonel Lettou's words... may not hold so much sway anymore.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: It is no longer safe here. You all must find some way to relocate somewhere else.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: But where would we go?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: In vain, she lifts her head and glances to the underground passage, its walls of concrete pitch-black.
She, like every other citizen trapped in Londinium, like Heidi, is left at a loss.
Please, be strong for a little while more, Molly.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: A woman once told me that it is a must, that Victorians safeguard their homeland.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I trust her. I trust that by our efforts together, we can build peace.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Haha, what a superficial piece of speech. I'm sure if Golding heard, I'd have her laughing at me again.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: She knows she hasn't convinced anyone. As the crunching of a tank rumbles through the street outside, the two hang their heads low, gravely low.
I just wanted to come and see the place she lived. And... pick up a letter she'd stowed there.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: So you know she's...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Mm.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: The din of war engulfs all language.
Molly approaches Heidi, stands on faint tiptoes, and wraps her tightly in a hug, gently patting her back.
Go.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Relaying intelligence out of both the Sarkaz and the dukes' sight is growing more dangerous of an ask, isn't it?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: Your last reply hasn't even arrived in my hands, and yet here you are beating it to the punch.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: Haha, quite... you're as shrewd as ever.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: It's like I hardly needed to write what I did at all, let alone see you in person.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I'd be very disappointed if so, Heidi.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: You tell me of how things are trending outside, update me on the Self-Salvation Corps and its supporters across each district...
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: And our vision fills with all the inescapable vanity and conspiracy of the age, all the might and right. Is it beyond our eyes to see anything else, now?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: ...Of course not.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Then let down your hair for a bit, and take a break.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: The children are out there frolicking in the street. This is when nobody enters the classroom to bother us.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: ...Very well.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I went looking per the leads you provided, but there's still no word from Ross.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: The situation in Sudean has ratcheted even tighter; I have to return there after. Do you remember the name 'Rhodes Island'? They'll reach Londinium very soon...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: ...I'm sorry, that all just bubbled up from somewhere.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: That's alright. You go on. I know the responsibility you're shouldering.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: You said before that if anything happened to you, you might need me to handle some intelligence work in your place. Even now, I'm not sure whether I'd be able to...
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: No, no, Golding, let's talk of something else.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Say—would you like to go to the theater?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Right now?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: Sometime.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Once... all this is over, and Victoria rings in peaceful days again.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: When we're not performers acting out this life, nor authors wracking our brains to slip our messages through the cracks.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: When we're just normal people in the audience, moved purely by the developments of a play, free from the terror of all the rumors offstage.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: We'll give each actor a bouquet in their spitting image, just like we used to—I've always felt those bouquets really complemented you.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Of course... Yes, why not.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: But... when will we find ourselves, once all this is over?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: Why are you always waiting...? And what makes you so able to wait?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: ...Golding.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: An unsent letter rests where it was placed, there on a dusty desk.
'Heidi, how do I break the children free from this age of violence? And how do I break free from it myself?'
'Oh, we impotent, defenseless book-lovers.'
'In this age where rationality and humanity have given way, whose follower should I be?'
That teacher who so loved to correspond in red pen as a joke, in her final letter, used a soft, plaintive black ink to write of her despair.
Heidi, there are times I see you looking so far ahead.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: It's hardly that I distrust you. I trust peace will come eventually.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: But then, when I try to look as far as you do, all I see is the next war, grinding the facade of peace to dust.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: You always seem to catch sight of some distant star, some unshakable faith.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: ...Nail on the head as always, Golding.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I'm just... following after the cleric we all so respected.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: It was her who gave me courage. It was as if she'd seen war, seen ruin, time after countless time... it was as if she knew we could one day be past all this suffering.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Mm. You've always been her follower. You can see her light.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: But I can't.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: So to my mind, the best I can do is to see what's in front of me, to trust in the here and now. So it goes for the vast majority.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: To trust our every class and play can educate the children, to trust in the little kindnesses we do the Self-Salvation Corps. It's better than cold selfishness, than a rudderless drive.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: I... want to trust that what our lives are now is still worth something, just as I trust in you.
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: You can trust in me, Golding. You can write of this all in a letter, so I might remember for you too.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: In that case, supposing I forget one day, you must make it in time to remind me. Deal?
attributes.name: Golding

attributes.content: She'd long... arranged a Messenger to hand me an office key.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I couldn't make it.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Countless letters and clippings still fill the deskside suitcase. They are all that's left. Heidi needs not read, for they were all sent by herself.
She came here to find again the true, inner feelings she'd divulged all those years ago.
She said as much to Golding: If I forget the grief and the roars I take down in my letters, then please, remind me.
You catch the guys from today?
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier A

attributes.content: Missed 'em.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier B

attributes.content: They'll all be stuck before long, anyway.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier B

attributes.content: Hah, true. No place to run. Those poor insects ain't ever seen what war really is.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier A

attributes.content: —What's that?
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier A

attributes.content: The two Sarkaz soldiers assigned to night patrol look up.
From atop a skyscraper's ruins come pieces of paper, floating down.
That's a lotta writing.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier B

attributes.content: Is each one the same?
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier A

attributes.content: No.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier B

attributes.content: Then who cares. Someone's just tossing out their wastebasket.
attributes.name: Patrolling Sarkaz Soldier A

attributes.content: The Sarkaz tosses the letter paper to the ground, and gives it a few stamps underfoot.
What a waste for you to throw these letters away... and how dangerous.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: That's alright. Our correspondence was never a signed one.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: And besides, they were just letters from me to Golding... odd essays and nothing more.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: She always liked to joke to me that since I'd be going my whole life in the guise of a third-rate novelist, covering for my intel gathering work...
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I may well be waiting until after my death to get the fame I deserve, when all these private letters can be published.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: So here we are... isn't this publishing, in a way?
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: I understand her choice. I understand how she couldn't bear this age any longer, just how despair and estrangement and hatred overwhelmed her.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Wounded compatriots unwilling to rise again, friends forced to suspect one another, children tasting suffering and hostility in the first years of their lives.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: How such stories are so omnipresent, yet so unspeakable.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: Depression. Sorrow. Indignity. Loathing. Penetrating critiques and satires, desperately longed-for images and memories.
Everything she endured. Everything she waited for.
The letters tell all across the dark street floor.
To the city, she lets out silent howl after howl.
But she's fully aware that no one will pick them up from the flagstone street slicked in engine oil, let alone discern the handwriting.
All falls still again. The only sound Londinium produces in return, the day-and-night rumble of the military factories, somewhere close by.
...And how powerless these words I play around with are.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: No more will there be letters.
attributes.name: Heidi

attributes.content: But, you know—I still feel it's a waste of sorts...
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: When Lady Golding put on plays for the children, she'd always bring up the suggestions you made for them in your letters, and how they always hit where it hurt.
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Lady Heidi, will you ever... still write your own thoughts, the way you did in those?
attributes.name: Molly

attributes.content: Back, to the ground, all the paper falls.

attributes.text: \n\nYou always say if the writing's gone poorly, it's fine to tear up the work. In that light, you'll surely approve of my act of casting away those old letters.
\n\nI've come to realize that my unconditional trust—and pursuit—of such a distant ideal is hardly a promised path, hardly bound to just come about under her witness with a finger's snap.
And the calls I once penned from behind as I followed in her tracks; those were no full answer to the lives we have now.
\n\nThis new life suffused in torment, from my confusion and my loss, from my own soul-searching. Something tells me—that I should be more than just a follower.
\n\nThis is... the first letter I write you. By my finite insight, by my frail and fleeting life, I want to press on ahead with others, and perhaps, come some time or other, I'll become a leader.
Oh, how I wish my critic could be not the ruthless present, but you instead.
